docs.lead_paragraph: HAS the technology industry a big and undeniably important slice of the economy -- become a business whose best days are behind it? In other words, is Silicon Valley turning into Detroit?

headline.main: Some see technology as a 'graying industry,' but others see a vibrant life ahead for applied computing in new fields.

docs.abstract: Some industry observers believe United Sates technology industry will see its competitive stature erode, as new global rivals undercut American companies on price and increasingly wrest lead from US in innovation; optimists disagree, holding computing's almost infinite malleablity means it will not age like traditional industries; ways in which computing is moving ahead include increase focus on uses of technology in specific fields; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Some see technology as a "graying industry," but others see a vibrant life ahead for applied computing in new fields.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Big Three Workers Give an Inch on Health Care'' (Business Day, March 22) reports that General Motors now spends more than $5 billion a year on health care for its employees and retirees, about $1,400 per vehicle produced in the United States.
docs.abstract: Stephen Burns letter calls upon management and unions to acknowledge that survival of auto industry and jobs that go with it will depend on replacing dysfunctional health care system (Mar 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mireya Navarro and James Sterngold, journalists in Los Angeles, were married on Monday. José A. Díaz Espinosa, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Hotel El Convento in Old San Juan, P.R. Ms. Navarro, 47, is keeping her name. She is a Los Angeles-based correspondent for The New York Times who writes for the Sunday Styles section. She was a member of the team at The Times that won the Pulitzer Prize for national reporting in 2001 for the series ''How Race Is Lived in America.'' She graduated from George Washington University and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia.
docs.snippet: Mireya Navarro was married Monday to James Sterngold.

docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN C. BAUM has seen a lot of changes since he started working six decades ago at the W.A. Baum Company, which his family owns in Copiague. For many years, he watched sales of its Baumanometer soar. Just about anyone who has ever been to a doctor's office or hospital has seen a Baumanometer, the inflatable cuff and the gauge with a column of mercury that doctors use to measure blood pressure. The device -- sphygmomanometer is its technical name -- was long considered the gold standard in the medical field.
docs.abstract: Profile of W A Baum Co, family-owned company in Copiague, NY, that makes and sells Baumanometers; president John Baum, 82, whose father, William, invented sphygmomanometer--inflatable cuff and gauge with column of mercury that doctors use to measure blood pressure--comments on company's ups and downs, declining sales of mercury sphygmomanometers and decision to diversify; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CHOICE is the driving force of capitalism. Choosy consumers determine what products and companies thrive or die as they pick among tubes of toothpaste or plans for cellphone service. Choice fuels competition, innovation and efficiency. These days, consumer choice has claimed a prominent new position as a policy tool: the prescription for everything from improving public schools to paring bloated health care costs to saving Social Security.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Choice Is Good. Yes, No or Maybe?

docs.abstract: Consumer choice has claimed prominent new position as a policy tool; it has become prescription for everything from improving public schools to paring bloated health care costs to saving Social Security; critics say that expanding consumers' options is not always good idea, and that sometimes government should choose for them; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: As choice is brought to bear on the nation's problems, critics point out that expanding consumers' options is not always a good idea.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: There are some points that I would like to clarify on your Wal-Mart article. Since joining the New Jersey community in 1991, we've created more than 12,000 jobs that pay competitively, averaging $10.11 an hour -- which is substantially higher than the state's proposed minimum wage of $7.15. We also offer benefits, including health insurance, for all employees. In 2004, Wal-Mart spent more than $6.7 billion for merchandise and services with 1,092 New Jersey-based suppliers. As a result, we're supporting 71,216 supplier jobs across the state. Last year, we also contributed more than $1.9 million to local charitable organizations, and backed local communities with more than $19 million in state and local taxes, including property taxes that help finance public schools.

headline.main: Opinions for Sale: Musings on Wal-Mart

docs.abstract: Wal-Mart regional corporate affairs director Mia T Masten letter on March 20 article on proposal to build three Wal-Marts in Deptford, NJ

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Implicated U.S. Soldiers Will Not Be Prosecuted Commanders have decided not to prosecute 17 American soldiers implicated in three separate deaths of prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan in 2003 and 2004, according to a new accounting released by the Army. Investigators had recommended charges including murder, conspiracy and negligent homicide. A1 Selling Fighter Jets to Pakistan The United States will sell F-16 jet fighters to Pakistan in a deal that State Department officials said would improve regional security. But the decision was immediately denounced by India as adding a fresh element of instability to relations between the two nuclear neighbors. A1 Falluja Struggling to Recover Some signs of life are returning to Falluja four months after American bombs and guns pounded much of the city into ruins. About a third of the city's 250,000 residents have trickled back since early January. However, the safety has come at a high price, and the high security has stunted the renascent economy and the reconstruction effort. A5 The delay in forming a new government in Iraq has stalled important projects at ministries and is sowing confusion among current government workers about their duties, senior Iraqi officials say. A5 Suicide bombings and armed attacks across central and northern Iraq left at least 21 people dead. The attacks, ending a week of relative quiet, included three suicide car bombings, the assassination of a high-ranking police official, and the killing of five Iraqi women who did cleaning for the American military. A5 Striving for Calm in Kyrgyzstan Kyrgyzstan's new leaders appeared to have succeeded in halting looting. As opposition leaders began filling in the ranks of a government, Russia and the United States both said they would work with the new administration. A3 Ailing Pope Views Service Pope John Paul II, silent and very sick, joined thousands at a Good Friday service at the Colosseum via a live video link from his private chapel at the Vatican. A1 NATIONAL A7-10;14 Ranks of Protesters Grow Outside Schiavo Hospice As Terri Schiavo lay dying, two more last-ditch legal appeals wound through the courts and the sense that this religious and political drama was coming to a grim conclusion. A8 Terri Schiavo's husband and parents once shared a life, but now they can't even agree on what to do with her remains once she dies. A1 Killer's Family Has Questions The family of Jeff Weise, the Minnesota teenager who killed nine people and then himself on Monday, say they wonder about the drugs he was prescribed for depression. A7 Blast Linked to Chemical Leak The refinery blast in Texas that killed 15 people was probably caused by a leak of two flammable chemicals, a member of a federal chemical safety agency said. A10 Problems With Passenger Data The Transportation Security Administration did not adequately monitor at least six airlines' transfer of sensitive passenger information to private companies and federal agencies in 2002 and 2003, according to a government report. A14 Colorado Professor Keeps Job A University of Colorado professor cannot be fired for controversial opinions like his comparison of some victims of the Sept. 11 World Trade Center attack to Nazis, the university said in a report. A9 American Farming Dreams A new generation of large animal farms, many owned by Dutch immigrants, have arrived in the Midwest and are pumping money into rural economies but are also drawing protests from environmental groups and homeowners concerned about water pollution, odors and land values. A7 Beliefs A10 SCIENCE/HEALTH Kidney Ills Linked to Farm Fairs Fifteen people in Florida who visited agricultural fairs recently have developed a life-threatening kidney disease or are infected with bacteria that can cause it, officials said. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Subway Delays Increase Despite Improvements An analysis of delays on the New York City subway system indicates that after years of improvements, the number of significant delays has started to increase over the last 18 months. The trend has raised concerns among some transit experts that service improvements achieved over the last decade may be difficult to sustain. A1 Tales Behind a Stadium Deal The story of how six developers joined the effort by the New York Jets to build a West Side stadium, is, in a city of cutthroat real estate deals, a mix of Olympic enthusiasm, commercial self-interest and politics. B1 Jersey City to Get Curfew A curfew will be imposed on more than 130 businesses in Jersey City, N.J., in the belief that shutting these restaurants, convenience stores and barbershops will curtail crime and vagrancy in a city going through what some call a crime crisis. B1 A Budget Deal in Albany The State Sentate and Assembly reached a budget deal that would increase spending by more than $1 billion over Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal. But political and constitutional questions still exist as the state struggles to enact a budget by next week's deadline. B3 SPORTSSATURDAY D1-6 OBITUARIES C6 ARTS B7-16 No Broadway 'Charity' The producers of a planned revival of the 1966 musical ''Sweet Charity,'' which has experienced much backstage drama since it lost its leading lady to an injury two weeks ago, said they were canceling its Broadway run. The news came just a day after the production opened to lackluster reviews in Boston, where it was playing a tryout run. It was to have opened April 21 at the Al Hirschfeld Theater. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-5 Wal-Mart Director Resigns Thomas M. Coughlin, who recently retired as vice chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc., resigned from the company's board after the company raised questions about his knowledge of fraudulent expense reports and invoices. C1 Deciding an Ex-Chief's Fate The directors of the American International Group, the insurance giant whose transactions are under investigation, are nearing a decision to cut all of the company's ties to Maurice R. Greenberg, its former chief executive, according to two people briefed on the board's deliberations. A1 Blockbuster Drops Bid Blockbuster Inc., the video rental giant, dropped its bid to acquire the Hollywood Entertainment Corporation the second-largest video rental chain, citing the likelihood that the Federal Trade Commission would reject the deal on antitrust grounds. C1 Groups Bid for Telecom Unit Two groups of investors made offers for control of Wind, the telecommunications arm of Enel, Italy's biggest utility. Italian officials have valued the entire business at 13 billion euros ($16.8 billion), setting the stage for one of Europe's largest leveraged buyouts. C1 Business Digest C1 EDITORIAL A12-13 Editorials: Add-on accounts add no value; the U.N. fights for its future; Tina Rosenberg on doctors and painkillers. Columns: David Brooks, Nicholas D. Kristof. Bridge B6 Crossword B16 TV Listings D8 Weather D6

docs.lead_paragraph: The more than 400,000 members of the National Guard and Reserve mobilized since the Sept. 11 attacks will be offered military health coverage for up to eight years after returning to civilian life, officials said Thursday. Eligibility will be limited to personnel remaining in the Reserve after demobilization, said Thomas F. Hall, assistant defense secretary for reserve affairs.

headline.main: Pentagon to Extend Health Coverage For Reserve Troops

docs.abstract: Pentagon says more than 400,000 members of National Guard and Reserve mobilized since 9/11 attacks will be offered military health coverage for up to eight years after returning to civilian life; say eligibility will be limited to personnel remaining in Reserve after demobilization; Guard and Reserve members can now retain health coverage for up to six months after active duty; under new arrangement they could retain coverage for one to eight years depending on length of their mobilization and the commitment to remain in Guard or Reserves (M)
